nodes.text: Conventional cost-benefit analysis presumes cost and benefit estimates are accurate and unbiased; if they are instead highly inaccurate and biased, then cost-benefit analysis is a fallacy for allocating public resources

Assembled the largest empirical dataset of estimation accuracy for public investments: 2,062 projects across eight investment types, 104 countries, 1927-2013; cost overrun measured as actual/estimated cost, benefit overrun as actual/estimated benefit; ran tests on full sample and a 327-project subsample with both measures

Cost estimates are highly inaccurate and biased toward underestimation: average cost overruns range by type (roads 24% to dams 85%); pooled average cost overrun about 1.39 to 1.43 (actual/estimated) indicating systematic underestimation

Benefit estimates are inaccurate and biased toward overestimation for several types (notably BRT and rail), with pooled weighted average benefit overrun about 0.94 (actual/estimated), indicating systematic benefit shortfalls on average

Cost underestimation and benefit overestimation compound rather than cancel: cost overruns are not compensated by benefit overruns, producing average ex-ante benefit-cost ratios overestimated by roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on project type

Statistical evidence strongly supports bias conclusions: Wilcoxon tests reject symmetry around one for costs and benefits (p < 0.0001), cost overrun data show extreme skewness and kurtosis, Bayesian models and subsample tests confirm robustness across time, geography, and investment types

Biases are systematic, persistent, and widespread: underestimation of costs and overestimation of benefits have held over 86 years and appear across geographies and investment types rather than being isolated to specific contexts

Behavioral explanations account for systematic bias: root causes include optimism bias, planning fallacy, overconfidence, probability neglect, and strategic misrepresentation that lead planners to underestimate risks like schedule, geology, scope changes, and price inflation

Measurement convention and data choices: costs proxied by construction/capital costs and benefits proxied by first-year benefits (chosen because full life-cycle data are rarely available); tests run on full sample and subsample of 327 with both measures

Data limitations and selection concerns: estimated and actual cost/benefit data are hard to obtain, some data rejected for quality reasons, sample likely conservative because available data tend to come from better-managed projects, and survival/selection bias may underrepresent poorly performing projects

Practical consequences: biased cost-benefit analysis leads to resource misallocation, initiation of projects with negative net benefits, and possible large macroeconomic harms in fragile economies when major projects fail

Conclusion: ex-ante cost-benefit analysis as commonly practiced is broken and highly misleading (the 'cost-benefit fallacy') because systematic biases make CBA a poor guide for policy unless corrected

Four recommended reforms to fix cost-benefit analysis: (1) systematic de-biasing of forecasts (reference class forecasting/outside view), (2) skin-in-the-game for forecasters, (3) independent audits separated from political influence, and (4) adapt CBA practice to democratic, non-technocratic decision contexts

Evidence that de-biasing via reference class forecasting works: RCF uses empirical distributional information from past projects, has been implemented at scale (UK, Denmark, elsewhere), and independent evaluations report improved accuracy

Mechanism for de-biasing: take the outside view by adjusting ex-ante estimates using distributional ex-post error data from similar past projects to mathematically correct optimism and planning fallacy

Policy recommendation and final conclusion: implement de-biasing methods, incentives, independent audits, and democratic-adaptive practices so cost-benefit analysis can reliably inform resource allocation; without these reforms CBA remains misleading
